Triggering Event: She sat alone in her kitchen, sipping coffee long past its prime, watching as her colleagues loaded into the squad car, laughing and chatting, oblivious to her absence. Another Friday night shift without her. She'd been hoping for a partner tonight, but the chief had other plans.
Generated Assessment: She's always left out when they go out together. It feels like she's never invited. I know it's not true, but it hurts to see everyone else having fun while she stays home. This time, she felt so lonely that she didn't even try to join in. The whole group was there, laughing and chatting, while she sat at home by herself.

Triggering Event: A grizzled, graying male officer watches as the young punk, barely out of his teens, smirks from behind bars, his eyes gleaming with defiance. The kid had been caught red-handed stealing from the very neighborhood he'd once played in. But it wasn't the theft that set the officer's jaw rigid. It was the mocking words etched into the boy's arm, a tattoo meant to taunt him - "Retired too soon," it read, echoing the graffiti scrawled across his own garage door years ago by a different punk, now rotting in prison. The kid's grin widens as he recognizes the officer's fury, igniting an old vengefulness that burns hotter than the badge pinned to his chest.

Triggering Event: A customer, barely older than her late husband, returns a wedding gift she'd given them. She notices it's still in its original box, unopened.

What is wrong with people? They're just so fucking selfish, no matter how nice they are, they'll always be a bitch at some point. Shit, I'm such an asshole for even talking to her.

In the dimly lit staff room, she unwrapped her sandwich, her hands trembling slightly. The clock ticked loudly, echoing the emptiness of the space around her. She had been working back-to-back shifts, each patient a grim reminder of life's fragility. Today, Mrs. Thompson, her favorite, hadn't made it. Her heart felt like a lead weight in her chest as she took a bite, the taste of nothingness filling her mouth. The door creaked open, revealing a young doctor, his face pale and eyes hollow. "Another code blue," he said, before disappearing into the bustling ward. She sat there, alone with her despair, her untouched sandwich growing cold on the table.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

She rushed into the precinct, her uniform stiff with sweat despite the chill of the night air. The clock's hands seemed to spin as she tried to fill out the report before her shift ended, each tick echoing the pounding in her temples. Her divorce papers sat unsigned on her kitchen counter, a constant reminder of the failure that clung to her like the stench of crime scene evidence. As she finally finished typing, her captain approached, "Another call came in. Domestic violence." She felt the familiar knot of tension tighten in her stomach as she grabbed her keys, stress coiling around her like barbed wire.

"I didn't exactly 'get' it," her captain replied dryly, his voice laced with an undercurrent of annoyance. "It was already there when I walked in." She forced a laugh, but her eyes betrayed her unease. "Oh, okay. So, you're saying—" "You think you're saying something else," he interrupted, his expression unyielding. "You're thinking, 'This isn't another case of domestic violence; this is personal.'" Her face flushed, and she shook her head vigorously, trying to clear the thought from her mind. "No, no, nothing like that! It's just... I don't know how these things happen, right?" The captain raised an eyebrow, his gaze piercing through her denial. "Don't play dumb, Detective. We all know why you're here tonight." She looked down at her feet, feeling the weight of his words settle heavily upon her. "I'm sorry, Captain. I really am. Triggering Event:
Scenario:

He sat alone in his lab, the hum of machinery his only companion. The clock crept past midnight; another Saturday night spent under the cold glow of fluorescent lights. His colleagues had left hours ago, their laughter echoing down the empty hallways before disappearing into the night. He stared at his experiment, willing it to work, but even the science couldn't keep loneliness at bay tonight.

He couldn't shake the feeling that time was running out, that soon he'd lose all chance to heal, all hope of finding happiness again. Triggering Event: He found their wedding photo, tucked behind a cookbook in his cluttered kitchen cabinet. The image stared back at him, her smile still bright and carefree, his own face beaming with a love that now felt like a bitter joke. He ripped it in half, letting the pieces flutter to the floor. "I hope you're happy," he muttered, more spiteful than he intended.
Generated Assessment: He can't believe he didn't see this coming. He had been so blinded by his own happiness for them that he never stopped to think about how things could go wrong. It's not fair; he thought they were perfect for each other. But now he knows better. This isn't just about the divorce. It's about everything else too. He has to deal with the fact that she changed after they got married, became so much more critical. She started focusing on what was wrong instead of looking for solutions. And then there's the whole thing with the kids. They don't even know their father. What kind of father would he make? He feels like a failure already, and this just makes things worse. Maybe if he had stayed friends with her before all this happened, none of this would have been so painful. But it is, and he needs to get over it. He can't let himself feel sorry for someone who chose this path willingly. That wouldn't be right. Besides, he thinks he'd be just as bad. He's seen her side, but he hasn't really considered hers either. Maybe she has a point. Maybe she does deserve someone better. Still, he can't help feeling guilty because he knew about the affair months ago. If only he had confronted her sooner, maybe things could've been different.
